title: 113_s274
content: The Act may be cited as the "Children Eating Well Act" or the "CHEW Act". It includes definitions for various terms. The Act, also known as the "Children Eating Well Act" or the "CHEW Act", defines terms from the Elementary and Secondary Education Act of 1965 related to education agencies and schools. It also defines "programs to promote healthy eating and nutrition education" as initiatives that enhance students' ability to choose and consume healthy foods. The Act, also known as the "Children Eating Well Act" or the "CHEW Act", emphasizes the importance of promoting healthy eating habits among students by providing education on making informed food choices using scientifically sound and developmentally appropriate materials and methods. The Act, also known as the "Children Eating Well Act" or the "CHEW Act", promotes healthy eating habits through education with nutrition materials aligned with Dietary Guidelines for Americans and professional development programs for teachers and school staff. The "CHEW Act" promotes healthy eating habits through education and professional development for teachers, school staff, and food service workers to teach healthy eating and nutrition effectively and promote a healthy school culture. Programs to promote healthy eating and nutrition education. Local educational agencies receiving assistance under part A of title I of the Elementary and Secondary Education Act of 1965 must develop and implement programs promoting healthy eating and nutrition education in all schools served by the agency. This may include integrating such programs into various activities. Local educational agencies must develop and implement programs promoting healthy eating and nutrition education in schools, including integrating activities that emphasize knowledge of healthy foods and a balanced approach. The curr_chunk emphasizes promoting healthy eating through a variety of foods, balanced diet, physical activity, and wellness activities to improve student knowledge and skills related to nutrition. The curr_chunk focuses on promoting healthy eating and nutrition education in schools by monitoring efforts and consulting with various stakeholders. The curr_chunk emphasizes nutrition education in schools through consulting with stakeholders and collaborating with organizations for guidance. The curr_chunk focuses on collaborating with various organizations and government authorities to promote healthy eating and nutrition education programs. The education and obesity prevention grant program, established under the Food and Nutrition Act of 2008, provides technical assistance for designing programs to promote healthy eating and nutrition education in schools, working with wellness councils to develop and evaluate these programs, and integrating them with local school wellness initiatives. The education and obesity prevention grant program supports integrating healthy eating and nutrition education programs with local school wellness policies and providing professional development in nutrition education to school staff. States receiving assistance under the Elementary and Secondary Education Act must comply with these requirements. The Secretary of Education requires states receiving assistance under the Elementary and Secondary Education Act to submit periodic reports on nutrition education programs. An inter-agency task force will be established to review and recommend effective nutrition education programs for schools. An inter-agency task force will review and recommend nutrition education programs for schools, with authorized appropriations for fiscal years 2014 through 2019.
